title: How To Make Healthy Snacks More Exciting
summary: There’s no easy fix for changing eating habits for the long run, but you can speed up the process by making healthy snacks more exciting for your child in ways that are both fun and approachable. Show your child why you eat the way you do and why you want to be healthy. Rotate the healthy snacks with the unhealthy ones so they don't feel like they’re missing out or getting forced to eat something they don’t like. Let them help you make healthy snacks in the kitchen and let them help pick out what you want.

content.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t Shout, Don\u2019t Shame, And Don\u2019t Threaten"),mdx("p",null,`No matter what you\u2019re trying to accomplish as a parent, yelling, shaming, and threatening are always a bad idea. While you may want to help your child see the error of their ways and be more open to new choices, using any of those negative tactics will only drive them away.
Children respond best to positive reinforcement and gentle guidance that comes from a place of trust. You want them to feel like they can be open with you and that you will listen to their concerns without judgment.
There\u2019s no easy fix for changing eating habits for the long run, but you can speed up the process by making healthy snacks more exciting for your child in ways that are both fun and approachable.`),mdx("h2",null,"Be a Role Model"),mdx("p",null,`Kids are much more likely to try new foods if they can see their parents doing so first. This is the easiest way to make healthy snacks more exciting for your child. And the best part is that you don\u2019t even have to try a new food you aren\u2019t sure about. You can just eat the way you usually do. The only difference will be that you are eating the healthy snacks your child is trying.
As you are doing this, you can talk to your child about why you eat the way you do, and let them know you are trying new things because you want to be healthy. Most kids will be very interested in why you eat the way you do and will probably have lots of questions. This is a great opportunity for you to be honest and open with them about why you eat the way you do. It will help them feel more comfortable trying new things themselves.`),mdx("h2",null,"Show Them By Making Healthy Snacks"),mdx("p",null,`If you\u2019re trying to get your kid to try a new food and they aren\u2019t having any of it, try making healthy snacks with the stuff they do like. If you\u2019re trying to get them to eat more fruits and veggies, try making smoothies with bananas, blueberries, or strawberries. Or if they like yogurt, try making a fruit-based version with less sugar. You can add as many veggies as you\u2019d like to these kinds of snacks without your child even knowing they are there. Your child might not like eating a raw carrot or green bean, but they might enjoy eating yogurt with blueberries and granola or a fruit-based smoothie.
If your child likes chips, try making baked versions at home with healthier ingredients instead.`),mdx("h2",null,"Let Them Help In The Kitchen"),mdx("p",null,`If you have kids old enough to safely use a knife, you can try letting them help out in the kitchen. This can be a great way to make healthy snacks more exciting for your child because kids often like to make things themselves. If they helped make the healthy snack, they might be more inclined to eat it. If you have a little one who can\u2019t help out in the kitchen, you can still try changing things up by letting your other kids help you make the healthy snacks their siblings eat.
If your kids are too young to help with making healthy snacks, you can still try letting them help you pick out what you want to buy. Let them pick a few options, and then let them help you choose which one you will buy.`),mdx("h2",null,"Rotate The Healthy Snack Options"),mdx("p",null,"To avoid getting in a rut where your child starts to expect the same healthy snacks over and over again, try rotating your healthy snack options every so often. You can also rotate the healthy snacks with the unhealthy ones so they don\u2019t feel like they\u2019re missing out or getting forced to eat something they don\u2019t like. Making healthy snacks more exciting for your child by rotating their options means they can keep trying new things and not get bored of eating the same foods over and over again."),mdx("h2",null,"Help Them Explore New Foods"),mdx("p",null,`Even if your child does like the healthy snacks you offer, there\u2019s a good chance they haven\u2019t tried enough of them to meet their daily nutritional needs. This is often the case with kids who are picky eaters. They like certain foods, but they don\u2019t like other foods, which means they aren\u2019t getting enough of the nutrients they need to be healthy.
You can help your child explore new foods by letting them choose one new thing each week to add to their diet. This can be any kind of food they want, even if it isn\u2019t healthy. This way they can explore the full range of foods they can eat without being too restrictive.`),mdx("h2",null,"Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,`Healthy eating is a skill that doesn\u2019t come naturally to most of us. We have to learn as kids, and we have to keep learning as adults. Along the way, there are lots of temptations that can get in the way of healthy eating, and there are lots of obstacles that can stand in the way of learning new habits.
Even if your child enjoys healthy snacks now, they may not always feel that way. There will be times when the healthy snacks aren\u2019t enough, and there will be times when your child just wants something different.
If you follow these tips, you can make healthy snacks more exciting for your child and help them find a healthy balance in their diet that they can maintain for a lifetime.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Stick to Your Healthy Eating Goals

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The New Year brings new resolutions and the challenge to stick to them. But how can you make sure you succeed this time? Planning and preparation are key to any endeavor, including sticking to your healthy eating goals in the New Year. Thinking ahead and making a plan will help you avoid pitfalls and stay on track. After all, it\u2019s not about failing once but rather keeping failure at bay so it doesn\u2019t creep up again next year.
Many people struggle with their eating habits because they lack structure or fail to plan ahead. That\u2019s why creating a strategy is essential if you want to maintain this commitment for good. Whether it\u2019s going on a diet, cutting out certain foods or reducing your intake of fats, proteins or carbs \u2013 there are different ways how you can achieve your goals. Here are some helpful tips:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Get Moving When You Don't Have Time for the Gym

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`New Year, same old resolutions. If you\u2019re anything like the majority of people, chances are that you have made the same resolution to get fitter, healthier and happier this year as you did last year. But with a packed work schedule, social calendar and everything else going on in your life it can be difficult to find time to hit the gym or take up that new Zumba class you signed up for last October but never went to again.
And yet so many of us do manage to get moving. Yes, it might involve setting your alarm an hour earlier than usual, waking up on Saturday morning instead of Friday night and putting in some serious dedication \u2014 but it is possible. So if you\u2019re struggling to find time for the gym here are some creative ways how you can get moving when you don\u2019t have time for the gym:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Eat Healthy When Eating Out
The Benefits of Regular Exercise - And How to Get Started

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"Getting into a regular workout routine is something that\u2019s a lot easier said than done for most people. While some of us have it easier than others when it comes to fitting fitness into our busy lives, we all struggle with different things at one point or another. It\u2019s easy to let other responsibilities fall by the wayside and not get moving, so you need to be strategic about how and when you work out. While there are many different benefits to exercise, the biggest thing that it has to offer is stress reduction. If you\u2019re looking for ways to reduce your stress in your everyday life, adding exercise to your routine is a great place to start. Here are some reasons why getting your sweat on regularly could be exactly what you need right now:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Ways to Make Your Commute Less Stressful

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`When you think about your daily commute, it probably doesn\u2019t strike you as being particularly stressful. In fact, many people see their daily drive to work or school as a time for peace and quiet. After all, what could possibly be stressful about getting from point A to point B?
It\u2019s true that your commute isn\u2019t inherently stressful. In theory, it\u2019s just a short period of time each day when you go from home to work (or vise versa). But even the most seemingly insignificant details can make a big difference. Read on to learn more about how you can reduce stress during your commute and get to work happier every day!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Eat Healthy on a Busy Schedule

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Eating healthy on a busy schedule is no easy task. It\u2019s not like we all have hours to cook and prep the perfect meal after a long day at school or work. So how are we supposed to eat right when there\u2019s barely time to even pick up fast food? Well, the answer isn\u2019t as hard as you might think\u2026 If you are ready to take control of your diet, then read on\u2026
If you feel like your life is always in hyper-speed and there\u2019s never enough hours in the day to get everything done, then you know exactly how these pressures can lead to unhealthy eating habits. But that doesn\u2019t have to be the case forever. Even with a busy schedule, it is totally possible for anyone to eat healthy meals regularly.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make Healthy Eating Easier with Leftovers

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Are you feeling so over-whelmed with the new year and its resolutions that you\u2019ve decided to skip lunch for the foreseeable future? Or perhaps you\u2019re just exhausted by how much effort it seems to take to eat healthy. While eating well isn\u2019t as simple as following a diet \u2014 there are so many different factors that go into it, and we all have our own personal preferences when it comes to what makes a meal healthy. But, there are ways to make eating well a piece of cake. Leftovers are one of those ways!
A meal made from scratch is an excellent way to ensure that you\u2019re staying on track with your New Year\u2019s resolutions. However, cooking every night is not realistic for most people. That doesn\u2019t mean you can\u2019t enjoy home-cooked meals without going through all the stressors of making them yourself \u2013 leftover cooking is your solution!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Make Healthy Eating a Part of Your Lifestyle

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...a}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...a,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`You probably know that eating a healthy diet is important. After all, five out of the top 10 causes of death in America are linked to unhealthy eating habits. However, it\u2019s not always easy to eat healthy. Work, school, family obligations and other commitments often make it challenging to follow a healthy diet on a daily basis. Fortunately, there are ways to make healthy eating a part of your lifestyle instead of an awkward obligation once a week or so.
And while we all have our moments when we crave junk food or a big greasy meal after a stressful day, making healthy eating a part of your everyday life can have profound benefits. A balanced diet filled with lots of fruits and vegetables lowers risk for almost every disease and helps you feel better mentally and physically. Follow these tips to help you integrate healthy eating into your daily routine as seamlessly as possible.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: The Benefits of a Plant-Based Diet
